Sarno goes on to explain that the root cause of most back pain is not a physical problem with the spine or muscles, but rather a result of repressed emotions and stress. He argues that the brain creates pain in the body as a way to distract from and cope with emotional pain. This can manifest in a variety of ways, such as muscle tension and spasms, as well as nerve and joint pain.

In order to heal from back pain, Sarno argues that individuals must first understand and acknowledge the emotional causes of their pain. This requires a shift in perspective from viewing the pain as a physical problem that needs to be fixed, to recognizing it as a psychological symptom that can be treated through emotional exploration and expression.

The book offers a range of techniques for achieving this shift in perspective and addressing the underlying emotional causes of back pain. These include journaling, meditation, and psychotherapy. Sarno also emphasizes the importance of self-awareness and mindfulness in preventing the recurrence of pain in the future.

Overall, "Healing Back Pain: The Mind-Body Connection" offers a unique and insightful perspective on the causes and treatment of back pain. It challenges traditional medical views of back pain and offers hope for those who have been struggling with chronic pain for years.
